docs.lead_paragraph: THEY met at Club Getaway. They became engaged on the stoop of the house they dreamed of buying. They got married in the front parlor of the house -- four months before they bought it. "You see, there was my best friend, and her guy was Marc's best friend growing up," said Dr. Iris Vardy Strauss, a very athletic orthodontist. "At one point, I'd actually been on the Getaway staff -- you know, it's that 'weekend camp for adults' up in Connecticut -- teaching mountain climbing and rollerblading. But one weekend, Memorial Day weekend last year, I was there as just a guest."

headline.main: Habitats/130 West 78th Street;A Couple's New Home Already Houses Memories

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your May 22 article on the erosion of privacy in psychotherapy did not convey the fact that mental-health treatment is the tip of the iceberg. People are beginning to understand the loss of confidentiality that computerized records and managed care have brought to all medicine, and they are jeopardizing their well-being by being less candid with doctors.

headline.main: Psychotherapist Has Duty to Maintain Privacy

docs.lead_paragraph: VACATIONERS, beware. As you take to the roads and skies this Memorial Day weekend or in the summer months ahead, you could be in for a shock more real than any encountered in this season's cinematic nail-biters. When the American traveler meets the bean-counters of health insurance, the results can be unsettling. Two powerful trends are colliding: the growth of American wanderlust and the boom in managed health care. Millions of travelers are likely to pay the price this summer, either in the money they spend for doctors and hospitals while away from home or in the frustration of long-distance haggling with their health plans over coverage and reimbursement.

headline.main: Managed Care and the Vacation;When Are We Gonna Get to the Doctor's?

docs.lead_paragraph: SAY "biotechnology" and watch investors' eyes either smile in excitement or glare in exasperation. But no matter which way your eyes usually go, two articles in Worth magazine's June issue may intrigue you. Both paint complimentary pictures of two industry players, one of which is not yet publicly traded.

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey authorities have accused a Bergen County psychologist of masterminding a medical-insurance scam that was said to involve about $3 million in fraudulent claims and kickbacks to public employees, including teachers, officials said today. The psychologist, Carl H. Lichtman, 50, of Ridgewood voluntarily surrendered his license to practice last October and is scheduled to appear Tuesday in State Superior Court here, apparently in response to a state criminal complaint, officials said.

docs.lead_paragraph: Consumers who turn to their state insurance regulators for help when shopping for health or automobile insurance may be getting bad information, a survey suggests. A national study by the Center for Insurance Research indicates that state insurance regulators provided correct answers to basic questions about health insurance between 43 percent and 65 percent of the time.

docs.lead_paragraph: While foreign-policy makers have trouble even defining the post-cold-war era, Washington deal makers have already figured out how to make millions in it. A cottage industry of consultants, business executives and lobbyists are tapping into one of Washington's least-known pools of money: international development banks. Foreign aid budgets are shrinking, but these banks are growing. Each year they generate some $30 billion in contracts.

headline.main: In Post-Cold-War Washington, Development Is a Hot Business
